headline: Company reputation does not match reality
pros: Salary is in line with competitors
cons: There is a culture of bullying from team leaders and senior staff to lower level staff. This is hidden with a veneer of pretending to care about staff progress, career journey and personal wellbeing, but then will use any information you provide against you and gaslight you into believing whatever may suit their agenda at the time, manipulating you into thinking you are not good at your role or are at risk of losing your job. There is a nasty culture of management and senior staff talking behind staffs' back; this has become a normalised and accepted behaviour.  Team leaders are not looking after the needs of their teams; instead they serve themselves first and foremost regardless of the consequences to their team. The office politics create a toxic environment that will eat into your self esteem and make you feel self conscious and distract you from thriving while doing your job. For a company that prides itself on having one of the best cultures to work in, I am very disappointed in how EY looks after it's executive assistants and general administrative staff in CBS. My experience with some colleagues has been great, there are some fantastic people working for EY, but the difference between the culture reputation and culture reality is shockingly vast, and overall experience has been pretty appalling.

headline: A great place for working fathers
pros: There are flexible work arrangements allowed for certain employees for maternity leave, paternity leave, jury duty, secondments, sabbaticals, global travel, medical leave, and other personal days.  In addition, some chosen few employees are allowed to work from home when they feel the need.  In fact there is one case where an employee is allowed to come into the office a few times a month if they feel up for it.
cons: When the heretofore mentioned employee works from home the preferred method of communication is to phone in a few times a day, talk more, listen less, focus on the perceived shortcomings of everyone else who is in the office that day, and complain about why those that actually show up for work are 'always' late to the office.  Contrast this to other managers that are required to work around everyone elses' schedules and still required to be in the office early every day of the week with few exceptions.

headline: EY GDS TAS Gurgaon
pros: Opportunities for international secondment on short term assignments. Reasonably good payscales. Good place for relatively junior people who are just beginning their careers to see how a large consulting firm thinks.
cons: Tons of things are wrong with this company. It just borrows the EY brand name but beyond that is run like a typical lala shop by the two partners. Impractical targets are set. Those who do not perform or are seen as questioning the policies are given a PIP and asked to leave. A group of people close to the senior management is allowed a lot of freedom in decision making but beyond this group, allunfair means are used to judge people subjectively. Those who question the authority of the partners are either subjected to ridicule and public humiliation or ignored completely during the appraisal process. The hopeless HR team has no powers over anything and are happy being mute spectators. Favoritism is so rampant, folks take it as given. The senior global leaders have no idea or simply don't care how this place is being run or how the EY brand is being misused. A real toxic culture.

cons:
Compensation doesn't even come close to industry; titles have very wide range of experience and skills (e.g. can meet a manager with 4 yrs exp, and one with 15 yrs); some individuals' mentality are locked into titles and rank; some get ahead through the usual Finance\Banking methods (competitive by taking credit, delegated negativity, etc.).

headline: Great Place to Start a Career
pros: Big 4 consulting companies like EY are great places for young consultants to start their career.  There is access to training, research materials, and mentors.  It exposes you to practiced and proven methodologies and processes. Also the list of contacts and opportunities are large.  You can really take advantage of things by soaking up as much knowledge as possible.  Just make sure that you learn to think for yourself.
cons: Long hours, average pay and benefits, and lots of travel.  These are alright if you are younger, but the rewards for consultants with families is not that attractive.  Turn-over at the mid-level is quite high, sometimes leaving a gap in knowledge and skill level between the partners and the staff.

headline: Inconsistent work-life balance depending on senior management
pros: If you work for an effective senior manager, the job is great. You learn a ton, the work-life balance is manageable, feedback is clear, and overall job satisfaction is high.
cons:
If you work for an ineffective senior manager, the job can be miserable. It can be very difficult to learn because expectations are not clear, work-life balance can be non-existent because the senior manager wastes your time, feedback is all over the place and inconsistent, and overall job satisfaction is low. 

EY does not currently have upward feedback so if you work for an ineffective senior manager who has friends in high places (partners, practice leadership, etc.) there are little to no ways to fix the issue without angering the senior manager and, in turn, getting poor reviews.

headline: Consulting/Advisory: Conservative, toxic culture; Absent leadership
pros:
Salary out of masters programs is on par with other Big 4 firms
For some reason
cons:
- Leadership is stuck in the old ways the world works - they don't embrace changing trends or demographics, insisting that things stay how they have always been instead of adopting the digital strategies and technologies that we push to our clients. Consulting/Advisory is what is going to drive revenue over the next decade and leadership refuses to stop setting strategy and business policies focused on the Audit/Tax groups.

- We pay our own Amex bills, meaning if the firm disagrees with an expense, you pay it out of pocket until they deign to acknowledge it was a legitimate expense. Everyone I know has had to pay business expenses out of pocket with no hope of reimbursement due to the antiquated policies.

- Senior Managers and Partners are absent at best and yet live with God complexes that derails projects whenever they decide to give even 50% of their attention to the work at hand. Feedback is one way, meaning no one above a Manager can provide feedback on leadership. Additionally, company wide feedback is completely subjective, making end of cycle variance volatile and comparing individuals nearly impossible. 

- Projects are consistently understaffed in order to offer deals to clients so they pick EY instead of competitors as they are well aware that our reputation is not the best in the business, or even the Big 4. Work/life balance is a myth, and if you try to set boundaries you are punished.

headline: Place where you can develop your leadership and skills
pros:
1. One of the best leading public accountant in the world, there's a pride in doing your job.
2. Clear career patch, give your best, individually and as a team
3. Growing responsibility as your career level grows, ensuring that you are in the right track.
4. Fellow professionals from various backgrounds ensuring you to always motivated with your life and career goals.
5. Various clients with multiple industries, allowing you to get exposure on whatever fields you want to focus on
6. Nurturing your durability through tough busy season, and various clients backgrounds
cons:
1. Administration for transport and overtime is manual - hard copy
2. Long working hours are fine, the difficulty is when you have to face more than 3 clients, with same deadline, promising of lack of sleep and rest, particularly during the weekdays.
3. unpredictable situation such as immediate client engagements, although it could be challenging in a fun way, imagine facing tight deadline, and you'll have to face another client that you did not anticipate.

headline: Excellent exposure for fresh graduates, but once the 4 years mark is reached, will need to consider other opportunities.
pros: Good exposure and large client-base. Good training in terms of technical knowledge and interpersonnel and communication skills. Great knowledge-sharing system and a great database for audit and accounting issues and knowledge.
cons: Long hours, pay and benefits do not match up. No work-life balance. Need to improve on the job management process.

headline: Good learning school and CV boost, but otherwise not worth the effort.
pros:
- you learn a a lot of things in a relatively short amount of time
- experienced, friendly coworkers (both within and outside of EY)
- very good way to build one's network
- working for a Big-4  is an asset for one's CV
cons:
- besides conventional targets like revenue and utilization, there no real management strategy.
- the only 2 ways to progress to higher ranks are either by selling or by managing projects.
- the business model provides little incentive to build expertise internally, since this conflicts with the targets.
- progression and promotion do not depend on honest, fair evaluations. decisions are taken beforehand and evaluations are skewed to match the outcome.
- if you're not visible enough or if management doesn't like you, you can forget about career progression.
- traffic jams around Brussels have an enormous impact on work-life balance

headline: Give and Take
pros: EY is a fantastic place to start and grow your career.  The mentoring culture is ideal and the Partners truly care about developing the people.  The brand sells well in the marketplace, so, there is never a shortage of work to be done.
cons: In recent years, growth has become more challenging, and, the Firm has not done a good job of managing "onesmanship".  Unfortunately this has lead to backbiting and infighting rather than a focus on clients.

headline: "Upstairs/Downstairs" culture at EY
pros: EY has a database or program or department for anything you could possibly think of- amazing.
cons: The office atmosphere is toxic from office manager (and some staff) who should have retired LONG ago. The admins stay in the same position for 37-40 years, some of them. Toooo long! They need to shuffle it up to keep things fresh and to keep these people willing to learn new methods of working, make them open to new hires. As it is, it's toxic.

headline: Avoid EY like the Recession
pros:
EY looks excellent on CV.
The people at your own level whom you work with are great.
Well recognised client base.
cons:
Unless you are an audit machine with no life or outside interests, save yourself from entering this hell hole of a place. They believe in sucking the souls out of their young graduates by promising them a future, work/life balance and good pay and then take it away from them within the first few weeks of starting their new career. EY drills 'Values' into their employees, a means by which management expect their employees to carry out their work by (e.g. integrity, respect, blah blah..). Whilst most of the young professionals demonstrate these values, you will find it is the management who treat those below them the most disrespect I have ever seen in a company. I will not go into detail but you would certainly not want to be faint hearted.

Work hours are never ending and if you do not work late you are told you are not working hard enough. However, when you do work late, you may be pulled up on your supposed inability to complete the work during the normal working day. You cannot win and it is with this argument that the management avoid promoting their staff.

headline: Great way to start your career

cons: Just like anywhere, you should own your own career path.

headline: Great place to start your career
pros:
-Great company, very well organized with an emphasis on making a tough job easier on the employees
-Great benefits
-Young environment
-Great experience: A lot of different types of work, great training, you really do learn a lot in a short period of time
cons:
-The hours. Unavoidable in the industry, but busy season hours are as brutal as everyone says they are. 70+ hour weeks, working until 3 am sometimes during the week...that's no way to live
-Pressure to stay utilized: Even if you happen to not be busy, there's always a lot of pressure to stay busy, so you can't even enjoy the downtime.
-Along the same lines, while the compensation is above average compared to most jobs, you are not at all fairly compensated for the amount of work you do. No OT catches up to you real quick.

You do not get rewarded financially for working hard. If you work much harder than a collegue, you may get a 5 in your year end review as opposed to a 3, but this only results in an additional 4% of bonus, which when you look at the extra hours probably spend values your time at about $5 per hour or less.

cons: Lower pay than some of the other big 4 firms. I worked in both the Toronto and Vancouver offices. The Toronto office is better run, and was a much better experience (I loved it!). The Vancouver office needs to be brought up to Toronto’s level. Work life balance was better in Toronto, but impossible in Vancouver. Toronto office culture and environment was comfortable- Vancouver was awkward and cold and cliquy.

headline: You are pressured to advance your career whether you want it or not.
pros: Good salary, flexible work arrangement available which is great for working moms (but read the cons), programs in place for encouraging advancement for women and minorities, strong culture for measurable goals and career advancement, good benefits (401k matching, medical plans (no vision plan though) pension after 5 years).  In our group, everyone is friendly, if not slightly competitive, but no backstabbers that I've seen in the last 5 years.  Great place for those starting out, have no kids, can work long hours, and you'll be able to get your feet with and have an excellent experience learning accounting, and work toward your cpa license.  Very supportive of providing education credits, and has an annual EY University where they fly you out for a week long training to get your credits.
cons: Extreme pressure to advance career even if you don't want to, work load is enormous and never lessens and always feel like there is no end, at best you'll be rewarded with more work; always feel like you have to keep up with everyone else where the culture is to work all the time, early in the morning to late at night; at the manager level and above, they highly encourage you (read: pressure you) have to participate and promote national committees whether you want to or not.  All of this is great if you want to because you want to make partner one day because they want you to succeed and generate lots of money for the firm, but all of this is not great if you just want to do a good job but don't want to work a bazillion hours of overtime and want to be able to pick up your kid by 5pm without having to tuck him in at 8pm and join a call at 10:30pm--this is what they mean by flex work arrangement.  I've seen coworkers on "flex work arrangement" work nearly 40 hours every week but only getting paid 60% because they have to "keep up" with their workload because there is no one else to do it and the demands to complete work and remain profitable are great.  Not my idea of flex work arrangement, it's almost like bait and switch.   After doing taxes for 15+ years, and grueling tax seasons year after year, I'm tired of it.  The processes are extremely bureaucratic and what should only take in essence 5-7 hours to do all aspects of a return, takes 20 hours because of all the admin, billing and coordination involved to comply with national processes.  People I work with are great, but the pressures to advance and the stress from nonstop work culture of this place will make any work/life balance difficult.

headline: If IT is your focus, join the bandwagon.
pros:
Good culture.
Large growth in the advisory space.
cons:
Most of the projects that EY do have a large IT component. Don't get me wrong, IT is important. I, myself know a number of programming languages, databases and ERP systems, but EY focuses way too much on ERP implementation work. It does everything from PMO to writing tech specs in all the advisory branches (finance, supply chain, customer and of course EI). 

I don't think EY is a company for MBAs.

headline: Talks the talk, but does not back it up
pros: EY works to provide a flexible, dynamic working environment. And it is full of smart and motivated people. It also offers some ability to direct your career, within the context of its business goals.
cons: EY claims to care about its people first, but that is not true any more than any other business. Very non transparent compensation, disregard for people's career-building experiences when money is on the line in any fashion (even neglible amounts). It also has a bad habit of "dangling carrots" in front of people's noses to coerce them to stay, while in the long term portraying the situation differently than EY intends to treat it. Overall, EY demands loyalty from its employees, while returning none.

headline: Very good school for finance professional.
pros:
EY provides a great start for any person who wants to become a real finance professional to get required experience and develop necessary skills. Plus you establish your initial business network within the professional services world. 

Looking forward EY offers opportunities for both staying with the Firm and developing your career inside or going outside and giving a different direction for your further professional growth.

One of the best positive aspects within EY is an opportunity to meet and work with really great people, who are very interesting persons, ready to take new challenges and achieve new heights.
cons:
At some point you start feeling that you do not get a lot of new experience, but just repeat the same things from year to year. And this situation is not easy to change.

Working under pressure is a usual thing. This is OK for some time, bit probably not for the whole life.

headline: Bureaucracy at its Finest
pros: salary, benefits, severance package, retirement vesting
cons: Ridiculous policies and procedures founded in nothing but control; impossible to locate an intelligent human being when attempting to resolve intra-company issues (W4, independence, unemployment); constantly conflicting mandates (only bill 40 hours; where is that 75 hours’ worth of work); outstanding review with huge raise, followed almost immediately by assessment of “does not meet expectations;” absolutely could not care less about the employee as an individual; impossible to determine chain of command when issues needed to be escalated.

headline: Regretful waste of 10 years of my life
pros:
- Majority of Pros are at the junior level where you can rotate between advisory, Tax, Assurance etc and can find what you really like to do ..
- Some great people to work with but majority of the people get caught in office politics
cons:
- Work Life balance is the worst I have seen. 
- Management makes promises that they have no intention to keep
- Promotions are more focused on billable hours rather than the quality of work or the contribution to intellectual content of EY
- Compensation packages are on the bottom side of industry
- Management basically own you and if you are not responding to every beck and call, you are never getting good reviews. 
- Cutting cost in every possible way to a point where it has started to feel like a body shop rather than a prestigious top 4 consulting firm.

I am a social person so I like to talk to everyone, but I still can't figure out why people from other departments don't mingle.  It was a very weird atmosphere.  People would only stay within their departments and it felt like I was frowned upon for being friends and talking to other groups of people.  

That would probably be my only complaint of my 5 years working at E&Y.

headline: I was in risk consulting/internal audit in EY India in Mumbai location.
pros: Excellent work exposure right at the start. Lots of travel opportunities. From senior to lower management, all people are very approachable and helpful. You will almost always have some work. You will get to learn loads and loads and will always face some challenges somewhere. Strong clienteles. Excellent brand value which you will realise even more after you leave EY. Intelligent people around. Reasonably good pay masters. You will have less time available for fun activities but they do keep it. If you want to learn loads in a very short span of time then come to the Big 4s.
cons: Too much work pressure, so sometimes people get frustrated and vent frustrations on others. Stress can be quite high. Reasonable amount of office politics. Competitive spirit is high. Pay rise not very impressive. Bonuses are just about fair. travelling can take toll on you after some time. Some projects require extensive travelling and staying away from home. Bosses can be harsh sometimes on you.

headline: Good Experience but....
pros: Good experience, great people of all backgrounds and skillset. Different industries you can dip your feet in. Random benefits like $75 per month on phone, $500 per year on fitness
cons:
-You are overworked like a slave and as you move up, you work more. Staff hours on average are probably 50, with a peak of 85, senior hours are on average 60 with a peak of 95 (from my experience)
- Benefits are awful, they try to highlight 6% max, but they only really match 1.5% dollar for dollar after the first year
- You are only as valuable as you are willing to work. My partner stopped talking to me after I put in my two weeks. We had a good relationship before, and I told the partner my reason for leaving, and the partner understood and that was our last conversation ever.

headline: Loved EY, didn't love my role
pros:
EY has so much integrity as an employer.  I have never been with a company that displayed so much concern for their employees, their culture, and their values.   

While the work can be demanding, the people are some of the best and
cons:
I think career progression is tough and lacking in parity.  Promotion is more about luck, timing, and having a partner in your corner that job performance and impact.  My role, though in a leadership position, could be mind numbing at times and I often felt underutilized. 

Leaders can be indecisive and I found the task of solving the same problems year over year frustrating.

headline: Best place to start but may not be the best place to carry on unless you want to end up being a partner
pros: There are many reasons to work for Ernst and Young Global. Firstly, it is a good brand name. Secondly, it provides a very good training ground for the future finance professionals. Thirdly, they have a very good health care benefits. Fourthly, of late they are very much encouraging women, minority and diversity. Fifthly, the partners and managers are very open and approachable and last but not the least, the overall environment is very casual and homely.
cons: Flip sides are firstly the salary is not at par with the industry or other big four, secondly, the work hours can be very long and thirdly, sometimes politics comes into the play in deciding the promitions.

headline: Best of the Big 4

cons: If you do not set boundaries, your team will keep taking and taking. This is expected in our industry, so just be prepared. headline: Ok place to work but you need to sell, sell, sell
pros: Continuing education and curriculum is very good. Available thought leadership is good ... could be better, Ability to move up through the lower ranks (thru Manager) is very good. Great exposure to the Finance and Business world for someone just out college or graduate school. Experience gained will serve you well anywhere. Usually find yourself working with some very smart people.
cons: Politics are huge. More so then competitors I've worked at. It's obvious early on that promotion to and beyond Manager is all politics. Seen colleagues passed over because they were not politically aligned. Though every promotion metric was met or exceeded.  Eventually it becomes  "Up or Out".  You have so many years to move up.  Unspoken, but there. If your a seasoned  professional I'd not recommend EY.  Unless your a  "salesman" and being political a personal strong point.

headline: Great to start a career and pump up technical knowledge
pros: Networking, excellent methodology, big clients, a lot of pressure to be efficient and productive. Opportunity to learn and develop different skills. Very good benefits, flexibility of schedule and easy to negotiate work load depending on what moment you are going through on other areas of your life.
cons: Busy season is really tough, but is part of it. I usually count the days of 2 months to end busy season and relax again. Also we have to manage every single hour of work. So, it is hard to keep control of that. On feedback period it is a lot of pressure to deal with and high expectations.

headline: Fun, hard work and personal development
pros: EY has a culture that encourages knowledge sharing, teamwork and maintaining your integrity. The company provided me with numerous opportunities to learn about different industries and consulting tools as well as developing many different skills. Colleagues are great - intelligent, fun and pleasant to spend time with.
cons: Most of the time the hours were long and the reward was not always in line with hours spent. The management (Partners) were of very different quality with some individuals not really being the role models epxected.

headline: Prepare to document every step of the process
pros: The culture is people focused and great emphasis in placed on reinforcing the value of the people as an asset to organizational success. To this end, the firm provides an excellent benefits package, training and development opportunities and a "flexibility" benefit that makes work/life balance very attainable.  EY prides itself on high ethical standards and delivers on that commitment.
cons: Highly matrixed, disorganized structure. Lack of efficiency. Lots of red tape, making it difficult to accomplish the simplest of tasks without proper documentation. Poor or fragmented communication practices. Despite quality being one of the critical success factors, the actual quality of work outside of the audit function often leaves a lot to be desired.

headline: Excellent company, however pros/cons vary widely based on project and client.
pros: Great brand recognition, many companies look to hire from the big 4. Travel can be exciting. Great pension for those looking to stay with the company for 10+ years. Excellent opportunity to gain basic managerial experience. Work and experience is available to gain in virtually any field if you are willing to do "busy" work for senior managers.
cons: Hours can be long, work can be repetitive, must adjust to multiple management styles and change your work style to please them all on each individual project. Must answer to both the client and your manager as your boss. No singe direct manager so year end reviews can be very opinionated.

headline: Investment Review Case Handler
pros: EY has a working environment which matches the prestigious hi tech modern offices that you would expect from a 'big four' company. Whilst I was contracted for EY, through regular hub and team meetings, we were kept up to date about future plans, contracts and goals the company had and more importantly how the workforce was to be involved within these plans. EY made a good attempt to keep employees informed and within a good working environment.
cons: As one of the more mature contractors, I found that the renumeration was under par with what was on offer within the marketplace. However for a new graduate, the company seems set up for career progression for a employees looking to gain more experience.

headline: Best place to start in Accounting/Audit
pros:
Here are some of the Pros:
- Ernst & Young has by far the strongest audit practice in the bay area - meaning impressive clients to work on and build up your resume(Google, Facebook, Apple, HP, Intel, AMD, to name a few)
- Working with smart people on the client side allows you to learn a lot and quickly
cons:
Some of the Cons:
 - Low pay 
- Little reward for strong performers (both in terms of opportunities and pay)
- Long hours

headline: very hierarchical
pros: you can see very different things, great name to show on CV.  there are also some good people
cons: this will depends on the group you are working with but I have seen in many groups: very hierarchical: senior people will be people who joined some months before you and will often treat you in a bossy way especially when lacking skills in your area. You will have to ask feedbacks to senior, when you are staff(first 2 years) and they will exploit this to ask you unfair things or force you to stay long hours for free. I have found most people at EY are arrogant and dispotic.

headline: Excellent Company
pros: Ernst & Young is a great company to learn and grow as an audit professional.  The training is excellent, there are many opportunities to travel (or remain local if that's your preference) and they have an excellent  PTO policy.
cons:
The mentor/mentee dynamic could be better.  Counselors are not always available to discuss your improvement and progress within the firm.  

Additionally, you can get pigeon-holed into serving on one client for most of the year indifferent to your desires. Once an engagement has developed and refined your audit skills they are hard pressed to give up your time to other EY teams.

Although the benefits clearly outweigh the costs please understand "Big 4" firms have an abnormally high attrition rate.  They work hard, they play hard.  If you're not up for the challenge you probably should consider other options.

headline: Creating & Rewarding Mediocrity
pros: Perks are nice.  A lot of free meals and alt travel on the weekends from client sites.
cons: Partner/Directors have weak communication skills and the work is extremely boring.  If you want to work somewhere that provides a comfortable lifestyle both in and outside of work (sometimes outside - travel can be brutal on your personal life) but an environment that rewards mediocrity, then EY is the place for you.  Employees at EY and all of the big 4 do a good job of spinning wheels at the clients expense creating massive reports with countless superfluous billable hours.

headline: would collapse under any real pressure
pros: They have a great set of tools and training; the opportunities to learn are substantial.  Management generally displays a good deal of integrity about their business and services.  Emphasis is on collaboration, not competition.
cons: Culturally, people are very risk and conflict averse.  People are very reluctant to provide negative feedback or to deal with conflict, and it becomes a very difficult process to eke out concerns or negative feelings.  Instead, people respond very passively and avoid important issues.  Management is very slow to respond to personality problems, unless there is a clear-cut case of bias, discrimination, etc.  Otherwise they just shy away and hope the problem disappears, or delays decisions through committee.  Management has a very hard time articulating strategy on a broader basis - instead it is dealt with on a sale-by-sale basis and is done in a manner that resembles groping about in the dark.  Very few people can even articulate what is unique about E&Y vs. competition in a meaningful and compelling way - usually it is just  a recital of basic facts about the company.  Cost structure is too high and EY usually gets killed on rates vs competition...lots of dead wood in the partnership who are unprepared to deal with change...they tend to just defend old ways until biz underneath them evaporates and is gone.

headline: Good company to start
pros: A good place to start if you want a career in accounting. The Company serves a lot of cool clients in the Bay Area and there were a lot of opportunities to work on such engagements (IPOs, start-ups and etc.). Almost everyone I met here was nice, smart and driven. I enjoyed working with the great people here. The Company is very supportive of helping the employees getting their CPAs and CPE hours. Scheduling is flexible as long as advance notice is given properly. Experience at EY would bring up a lot of good career opportunities later.
cons: It is very hard to have a work-life balance, if there is any. Busy season drags longer and longer as the Company gets more and more IPO projects and private clients. Like other Big 4, the compensation doesn't match the hours/efforts put in. On certain engagements, it is expected to work on vacation and weekends.

headline: Great, if you like being an accountant.
pros:
If you really want to be an auditor or tax accountant or accounting consultant, career and salary progression is very clear. Being made a partner, however, will depend on lots of factors outside of your control.  

Great starting place for a job as an accountant or controller or even CFO at another company.

This is a premier company from a global perspective. No question one of the strongest companies in the industry, though that doesn't necessarily translate to being a fun company to work at. 

They pay for your CPA degree and even provide a bonus for passing it early.  

If being an accountant is your dream, you can't go wrong with EY.
cons:
If you do not want to be an auditor or tax accountant or accounting consultant, stay away. Don't even visit their webpage. 

This company is about doing an adequate amount of work in as many hours as possible in order to bill the client roughly what was billed in the past and work toward billing more in the future.  Creativity is stifled. I was told, very specifically by a manager, that auditors are not there to "help" the client, but merely to verify that they are doing what they say they are doing.  It is a babysitter's job.

Very simple tasks (like comparing numbers in multiple documents) are made extremely convoluted and time consuming.  Everything has to be done in a particular order because the whole process is regulated, and that is understood, but time-saving measures are not encouraged.  

Face time is very important. The intern doesn't leave before the associate, who stays until the senior associate is gone, who won't move without knowing the manager is gone, who doesn't budge until the senior manager is gone. The senior manager lives in fear of the partner, and so he works all night.

In all honesty, it is important work, and certain people are cut out for it, but if you like your creativity, and if you don't like the thought of working 80 hours to do a 40 hour job don't work at a Big 4 firm like EY.  

If you value money early in your career and are smart enough to get this job out of college, don't get this job out of college. Pay is insulting after the wining and dining they do during on-campus recruiting. Benefits are stingy.

headline: Senior Executive

headline: Work-Life balance is a platitude at best
pros: The work that EY does and the client portfolio they have is pretty good, and the pay and benefits are good, except for the caveats I will list in “Cons”. If you can take the grind, you can get pretty far and it opens a ton of doors when it comes to furthering your career.
cons:
Work-life balance is terrible. I don’t know of any office job where the expected hours per week are 45. Your workload completely rests on how realistic your client’s and managers’ expectations are, which in some cases includes working in the evenings, in unbilled hours “just to make sure the client is happy.” But here is the real reason why I give EY 2 stars. During my time at the firm, my wife had our fist child. EY gives 2 weeks parental leave to the nonprimary caregiver before their 1-year anniversary, but after a year, that becomes 16 weeks, paid.
My child was born, prematurely might I add, at 9pm on the evening before my one-year mark. I reported to work on that day. I put in the hours for a full year’s worth of work, and my kid was born after hours. However, they flat out refused to give me the time off, citing that “there is a precedent.” So I had a kid in the NICU and the company that “looks after their people” did not do squat to give me a little bit of flexibility in terms of giving my wife a break or giving me some appropriate time to bond with my child. 
That was the moment I decided I was leaving the firm, and the moment I became completely disillusioned in the work there. They are just like any other company that slaps these “generous benefits” on their HR sites and hiring materials to make you think they care, but when the time comes to have a human being give you some real help, they just won’t go beyond the agreed-upon minimum. They don’t care about you.

headline: 1540 Tech Studio - Good Boss, Good Compensation, Not Enough Work
pros: Very competitive compensation package, a ton of benefits, flexibility with office hours/working from home, you get to travel if you like that. The boss on my team was awesome he always stood up and backed my thoughts and opinions and although we sat right next to eachother he was never a nosey boss and didn't micromanage me. He trusted me to do good work and that's ultimately what led me to do good work. If you like the kind of work they do here theres ample opportunity to move up within the company. Overall it is a good place to work if you are later on in your career and have a family or if you really like very tech heavy, data driven design (which isn't my focus).
cons: It wasn't really my vibe in terms of company culture but that varies from person to person, I come from advertising so it was a little bit of culture shock. In general there just wasn't enough work, I found myself idling around a lot of the time and there's not a lot of room to pitch ideas since most of the clients in my office were on a project basis.

headline: Build a Better Working Culture
pros:
Nice London offices

Lots of soft skill learning available

Business services are responsive and helpful

Powerpoint skills are now through the roof. You will learn how to align all the shapes.
cons:
If you are hired as an experienced professional, then it doesn't matter what you did previously, you will be put on whatever engagement is available across the advisory business and that can be anywhere in the UK/abroad on short notice for long periods of time. It usually works out as a horrible game of pass the parcel, so make sure you have a good reason ready to try and avoid it being you

If you do not have a Partner who will back you up, you are at the mercy of the resourcing staff. 

When you are parachuted into a completely new subject area, if you succeed, then it's EY's success, if you struggle then it's you the individual who is to blame.

If you try and avoid that situation, you are called 'inflexible' and placed onto a Performance Improvement Plan 'to improve your consulting skills' i.e. the art of winging it when you don't know the subject area.

If you try and tell your Counsellor or Pod Director you are in the wrong team as you are being put on engagements that are not relevant to your experience, then you will be reassured and then ignored. See previous paragraph.

Team mates/colleagues will point blank ignore you before and after you have served a specific purpose that benefits them. Be ready for plenty of awkward lift rides. 

As such, there is next to no team spirit. EY have recognised this by trying to assign each other 'buddies' and 'family trees' forcing people to try and become friends with each other.

Your half year and year end reviews happen in a meeting you are not invited to. The scores you collate from your peers are rejected and your actual performance is decided by people who have next to nothing to do with you. 

I didn't actually learn anything new about my subject area during my time with EY. I solely relied upon my previous knowledge (when it was even relevant to my work).

Cheaper to eat outside as the canteen has no price reductions.

headline: Great for accounting and finance, still not a true advisory business

cons:
Long term rewards only come from reaching partnership which is hard to gain unless you are favoured by an existing partner.
Still an accountancy business at heart despite some forays into broader advisory

Business development and sales skills being heavily prioritised over delivery of client work skills - especially for longer term progression.

headline: EY gives you the opportunity to grow and pursue the fields you're interested in.
pros: The people are all amazing. I have rarely ran into anyone I haven't enjoyed working with.
cons: You have to be able to take initiative and manage your own career. If you are not willing or unable to do this, then this may not be the right opportunity for you. Additionally, there can be uncertainty regarding where you might be the next week as projects can start and end unanounced.

headline: Underpaid and Overworked
pros: People are usually intelligent and hard working. Teams are usually understanding of stuff that comes up in your life.
cons: The pay is unbelievably awful. When you’re a college graduate with $50k in debt, a car that barely runs, and a $1,000 a month rent (with a roommate) it’s almost insulting what they pay you. They could easily pay everyone more too, that’s the worst part about it. Partners easily make $700k per year (more than most brain surgeons), and I definitely think that’s too much for the job they do. They could easily shave a couple hundred thousand off of every partner’s salary and give it to normal employees, but they don’t because the company is led by a bunch of greedy people. It seems unethical to me that brain surgeons are making less than partners here.

headline: Ernst & Young is a great place to start a career, but if you just want a day job you should go somewhere else.
pros: The best reasons to work here are the name recognition and wide area of experience. There is a lot of opportunity get as broad or specific an experience as you would like as long as you have proven results.
cons: It can be hard to balance work and life, especially during busy seasons. At the manager level and above, you are expected to execute projects as a part of your "day job", sell additional projects to existing and new clients, and participate in internal company initiatives or contribute to the company. This leads to a heavy focus and indoctrination within the firm, but it can be hard to separate work and home. May senior executives do not appear to have this separation at all.

headline: Great culture, good learning
pros: Great company to work for if you care about work-life balance and are interested in financial services. Leadership is great at recognizing talent and providing opportunities to junior team members. Additionally, the people/culture and work-life balance are what would make one think twice before leaving this firm.
cons: Salary and benefits are commensurate with the other Big 4 firms but could definitely be more variable - tilted more towards performance. Bonuses are almost non-existent. Benefits (insurance, family support, etc.) are great

headline: If you are okay with monotony and a stable salary, its the place for you!
pros:
Ey GTH has the nicest environment for freshers, plenty of support, team leads who will take your ideas into consideration. It is a great place for women, there is no disparity and you might even do better than males!
They have so many cultural activities and you generally have a good work-life balance except for about 3 months in a year.
cons:
The work in EY GTH is demeaning, monotonous, will make you lose your brain cells and IQ.
GTH supports the other EY country offices so you can assume that you will be doing the tasks that no other self-respecting country team wants to do. You will do clerical tasks with fancy names but at the end of the day you are just a little better than BPO Staff. Shockingly I have found MBAs, engineers and phds work in a support function here. But then like i said if you do not major challenges, like a steady salary and like the people, you will stay for years in GTH.

Politics is there in every company but if you jell well with you leads, you will be given better things to do, more leave approvals and so on!

No cabs, no sodexo and really bad coffee!

headline: Ernst & Young
pros: The pros of working for Ernst & Young or any Big 4 are the opportunities to see a variety of projects and make contacts with upper level management at other companies/clients.  The other pro is there is a certain reputation that goes with working for a big 4 that makes one very marketable for when the day comes they want to seek employment else where.
cons: The cons of working for a Big 4 company is that the compensation is relatively low relative to the hours worked. You are also rarely treated like an individual and more like just another "number".  Although to be fair the same could probably be said about most larger companies.  There is also a lot bureaucracy and a certain hierarchy where the lower level positions are treated almost as slaves or indentured servants.

headline: You had me at yellow!
pros:
Working for a purpose led organisation with smart, engaged people to build a better working world is a very rare find. Our Oceania CEO, Tony Johnson, lives and breathes our brand and he's accessible. 

The flexibility for everyone, not just working parents, is delivered across the firm and the focus on gender and cultural diversity is a highlight.

The office - The new 200 George St office is sensational. Best part of town, amazing views, subsidised cafe and state of the art facilities.

The gym - There's a built in wellbeing centre delivering a range of classes and personal training.

The physio, masseuse and beauty therapist also are available on different days.
cons: Yes, the hours are demanding, but you'll expand and grow with the endless challenges and access to global colleagues.

headline: Fantastic culture and great opportunities

- Mobility, opportunity to work abroad and experience new cultures with both short term and long term secondments
cons:
- Although D&I is a focus area for the firm and there has been progress made especially this year following the George Floyd murder, there is still a lot of work to be done to improve race fluency at the senior levels whom are majority white males.
- More of an audit / bug 4 issue than an EY issue but the work life balance particularly in busy season is poor

headline: Toxic environment
pros:
Managers are usually flexible around vacation and any time you need off.  
If you work 40 hours a week, you don't need to take vacation if you take a Friday off.
Compensation is decent, but might be slightly lower than their competitors.
cons:
Resource managers don't give you an option for roles, if you are available, you go to whatever project needs to be filled, regardless of skill set, location preference, etc.  You get no say in the matter.
Only 15 days of PTO until you hit manager, then it jumps up to 25.
Since EY is primarily an audit firm, you and your family aren't allowed to own any stock that EY audits, regardless if you are on the account or not.
Work/life balance is almost non-existent.  Many senior managers and partners in the firm travel so often, they don't see their kids grow up.  I'm not sure why anybody decides to do that, but if you want to get high up in this company, you'll need to sacrifice your personal life.

headline: Be prepared to have no work life balance
pros:
1. Good growth trajectory, easy to get promoted if a high performer 
2. Smart people to work with
3. Good benefits, e.g. 401(k) plans, parental leave (16 weeks paid for both mothers and fathers)
cons:
1. They don't respect your career, and treat you solely as a resource. They have poor staffing practices (understaffed engagements, long working hours). They will ask you to skip trainings, vacations and would burden you with undue stress if you are marked as a critical resource for a project. 
2. If you are on a traveling project, then they would expect you to be in office 8am-10pm, and always available if something comes up (even midnight)
3. You would hope that all those long hours will help you at least in a monetary way, but it will not. Work 13 hours, get paid for 8 only. 
4. They will fire you if you do not meet your utilization targets, even if it is not something you could control. Culture of hiring and firing. 
5. No one will care about your growth and career trajectory.

headline: Great place for an international career
pros:
Probably the best place to have a truly international career, EY really gives people the opportunity to work anywhere in the world, if they’re interested. 
Another plus is that the company culture is very inclusive and people are encouraged to work in teams. This means everyone is pretty nice, you sort if need it to survive. I have seen knowledgeable, but difficult people get pushed out because nobody would work with them.
cons: The worst part about EY is that every group looks after its own P&L and thus you get boxed into whatever projects come to your group. Even if you have the knowledge and the experience to deal with a project that ended up with another group, they would still try to keep it to themselves.

headline: Good place to work if you don't mind it being corporate
pros:
I had great support from my manager and wider team. They were very helpful in encouraging me not to overwork and supported me with figuring out how to make part-time work in the role. 

Although I was 'just'  in a support function (my phrasing) my contributions were valued by the technical teams I supported and there were clear opportunities for professional development if you wanted to move up. 

Flexible working is embraced and facilitated very well (not just talked about)  - wide-spread use within the company of Skype so you can collaborate with anyone, from anywhere. 

Free hot drinks from a machine (not amazing quality but hot chocolate is great for a little pick-me-up!)
cons:
Office /EY global policy of hot-desking makes it hard to build meaningful relationships with colleagues and the office (2nd floor) had quite a quiet 'library' feel to it. That made it difficult to talk to people as I didn't like others listening in (for shy people life is hard!)  

Break area for lunch in Barbirolli Square was not separated from work area and didn't feel like a private, chilled or welcoming space to eat in, especially if you want to have your lunch by yourself. 

Expectation to work hard and play hard in order to build relationships and become embedded in the teams. But that is difficult if you already have a busy social life outside of work or just like quiet nights in.

headline: EY Knowledge
pros:
Company has a lot to offer to new college graduates or those that are on the career advancement path. Great benefits for their employees. They are really big on YOU owning your career development, hence your advancement and opportunities. With the help of your counselor you work towards creating goals that will challenge you and help your grow in your career.

If you are a global minded person, interacting with individuals from all over the world is amazing.
cons:
The same career development that is pro can also be a con as they see everyone advancing in their careers/moving on. Some individuals are content at their stage in life and career advancement is not a priority. There are more than other ways to stretch someone's goals and to challenge them. 

Work life balance and the expectations/demands are unrealistic. Global company so you have to be available to work with others in other countries/time zones. This sometimes equates to long days to accommodate. 

The hoteling does not allow for a sense of community or belonging (this where you reserve your desk (just a small workstation) by day or by week) you have reserve your workstation and move around frequently based on availability. If you do not have a permanent assigned seat. So no real feeling of belonging.

headline: Best Benefits
pros: I cannot work anywhere else because I cannot give up the benefits at EY. I receive 5 weeks vacation, 2 weeks of sick time, 6 months of parental leave with the option to extend 3 additional months unpaid. There are summer sabbaticals available unpaid for 3 months. Everyone has an option to have 2 weeks additional vacation unpaid every year, with the salary reduction being applied to your paycheck over 6 months. I have the flexibility to work from home some days if I need to. I cannot find another company with this much flexibility and vacation ever. My job is task based, so when I don't have work I don't have to show up at an office at a certain time even if I don't have work to do.
cons: As my job is task based, this means sometimes I have to work long hours to meet a deadline. I like the fact that I know which months those will be each year, and can plan around it. During the Spring, I work long hours (average 55 hours per week) without overtime.  Also, it takes 5 years to get to be a manager where I have this much flexibility. The first few years are tough. Auditing is not that glamorous. I might have more fun doing something completely outside of the corporate world., but this allows me to have money and lots of vacation to do the things I want to do outside of work. Another con is that the job is stressful, and if you don't learn to manage it, the stress can consume you.

headline: Great firm, but sadly have some toxic teams
pros: Firm has good reputation and good amount of big clients. Lots of oportunities to grow. The annual training is systematic and well designed, and provides an awesome opportunity to get to know people and make friends.
cons:
The comments below are specifically for Assurance team in NYC office. Overall, the culture was very top-down and assurance team was not sufficiently staffed. In some teams, because the managers/sr managers were overloaded already, they didn't have time to build or manage the team, or make sure team member were treated fairly. Therefore, it created a toxic culture that hands-on people tends to be the most overloaded ones and not given enough credit. To make it worse, this environment enabled some manipulative people to survive or even take others' credit. 

For new hires, although there were also get supporters like conselor and people advisor, there is a chance for how much help you could actually get (because these supports themselves could be busy or overwhelmed already, or barely in the office). Compared to what I heard about onboarding experiences in other Big Four firms, there are some other firm that is doing better in this area and make the new hire feel much more supported.

headline: Horrible experience, As good as committing su!c!de.
pros:
1)Its a Big four company.

2)Its giving free covid vaccine for all employees in specific locations(Mayanagri, Garden city).

3)Udemy business account to upskill(though they don't consider your skills while tagging to projects).
cons:
1)Work culture is not at all employee friendly, senior management doesn't consider employee requests. there is lot of communication gap. even after a year don't know where to go for some of queries(No HR, partners are gods)

2)IMPORTANT: If you join under EY India LLP, you will be working as a contract employee for other companies that too with 2 to 3 decades old technology irrespective of the tech you interviewed for.(i wish it was communicated b4 hand)

3)I was interviewed on Latest technologies but i was assigned with 2 decades old tech which i don't have any knowledge on.

4)You would be working from client locations, EY doesn't contact you either, thus no base for increment/bonus. It will be peanuts.

5)Releases are planned on weekends and you are expected to be working without comp off or extra pay as opposed to permanent employees.
You have to be working late nights and weekends and even holidays(without leaves). They will make it like that just to save their billing.(typical contract job)

6)Internet bills are not reimbursed by company even in covid time. Even for other reimbursements process is not smooth.

7)So overall they set a Gold Standard of Exploitation.

Most people don't stay long. High turnover.

headline: Tax Manager
pros:
-Multi-national presence which has its perks such as the possibility of doing rotations in other parts of the world
-Great client base due to being one of the Big4 accounting firms
-If you don't know how to do something, you can find someone within the firm who does so it provides awesome resources for absolutely anything
-Lots of young people to work with who are willing to give more than 100% to any project which allows for leveraging leg work down and also allows you to use your time to focus more on other important parts of the project
cons:
-Can get out of control in terms of hours you are required to work because the firm is driven on chargeable hours and one of the key factors they consider for pay is utilization which is the amount of hours you charge to clients which adds up to your time in the office (i.e. you can be in the office for more than 8hrs but real chargeable work could be just 5hrs so you need to spend a significant amount of hours working to hit your utilization goal set by the firm based on your rank)
-Cut-throat environment. It's all about getting the job done even if its at the expense of people 
-Fast paced and sometimes the pressure is so great with tight deadlines that there is no time to develop or teach people below you

headline: Analyst - transaction advisory services
pros:
Junior level people (like me) are great, as they are around the same age and have similar phase going on with their lives, so hanging our with them is nice

There are some nice projects and exposure to variety of industries

Currently the market is hot, so a lot of projects going on
cons:
Poor project management

EY still widely considered as an auditing firm, doesn't have as much weight in resume as people think

Work-life-balance; the nature of business (whether you work for buy-or sell side, project usually must be carried in ~4 weeks. This means that usually you will tbh work 70-100 hrs week depending on a project)

Partners don't care about their employees, only about their bonuses

On manager level, people are only interested in minimising their own work and outsourcing their work to juniors. 

Really generalistic function. You will not become a specialist (other than a specialist in transaction and M&A) in any specific industry. Considering that most companies don't execute transactions quite often, except PE firms, IMO you really can't leverage your skills outside the firm.  Surely you gain the infamous "consulting mindset", but that is obtained after couple of years.

Considering the hours, the pay is not worth it.  Over hours are recorded and paid out every 6 month, or you "can" use them for vacation time on 1to1 basis.

headline: Great Company Terrible hours
pros: The pros include the fact that you will be working with an incredibly smart set of people at all levels. Also, career progression is fast (if you work in Assurance or Tax, maybe Advisory too). I've worked in at least three different EY offices around the world, two of them in the United States. The culture varies depending on the country. However,  here in the united States, for the most part, people are a pleasure to work with, and if you enjoy working in teams while still having plenty of opportunity to shine in your own right, EY is definitely a great place to work at.
cons: Flexibility is earned, so don't expect to be a staff 1 or a brand new employee working at hours convenient to you. Here, flexibility (once earned) simply means  you will be flexible to work at any and all times. This means working late into the night, and not just in busy season, cancelling plans for the weekend, and working instead, sometimes working many weekends weeks at a time.

headline: Excellent firm to work for but remember no firm/company is perfect.
pros:
The firm respects people as individuals and offers the opportunities for individuals to shape their own careers in the areas most interested to them. 
Ernst and Young supports mobility in allowing employees to move between regional and country offices.
Ernst and Young provides high quality training for all its staff and sponsors specialist training from external providers as and when necessary. Ernst and Young sponsors its employess to obtain and retain necessary qualifications.
cons:
Staff are expected to work long hours during busy project times and this may include working weekends.
It may be difficult to leave particular projects if the project team are unable to find a suitable replacement or the client does not want this to happen.

headline: The consulting practice at Ernst & Young has a lot of room to improve.  Culture can be tricky and complicated.
pros: Good reputation and name on your resume.
cons:
Was hired as Senior Consultant.  My experience at EY was below my expectation.  
First, the consulting practice doesn't have enough projects or the right projects to keep people busy.  A lot of Senior Consultants ended up working on internal projects or pursuits, for a long time.  You learn little during the time.  
Second, some senior managers are really far from the culture that EY is proud of (supportive and collaborative).  You are mostly treated as a labor to work day and night, 7 days a week, without being appreciated.  You feel you wouldn't trust these people.  If you have a review with them, you feel your results and evaluations has been set up even before they listen to you.   It also means if they got a project, someone else will be considered even if you worked very hard for them and tried to please them. 
Third, make sure you select the office which matches your interest focus.  Each office may have different focus even within one practice.  If your interest is different than the office's focus, you will not get project from your office and have to follow someone else from a different office and fly every week for other projects.

headline: Flexibility
pros:
I am on the tax side so these are observations for EY's tax culture.  

The Flexibility is something I am grateful for.  Some examples of Flexibility are: 1) being able to work remotely when needed,  2) being able to go to the doctors appointment without having an approval. You make your schedule (within reason) as long as you get your work done.

There is Very minimal micromanagement as long as you get your work done.  Flexibility and minimal micromanagement are the top two things I've been able to distinguish EY from other Big 4 firms.

Travel opportunities to Argentina and India in your third year and beyond.

Huge professional networks (but all big 4 probably has that)
cons: There is a lack of coaching so you would have to be proactive and take your own initiative to learn or get someone to care to coach.

headline: A big name on your resumé, but GET OUT asap.
pros: Office view, good hours (but you need to fight hard for this), WFH opportunities depending on the client, there's an abundance of colleauges so you're bound to make some friends, there are some genuinely good people in management, the ability to basically be on paid leave when between engagements if you keep your head down.
cons: Pay, some very very toxic people in management who can hurt your career if they single you out, performance reviews are redundant as they aren't even taken into account come promotion season, clients tend to be difficult and if you don't have good colleauges or support on an engagement you'll be very unhappy, engagement teams are picked based on friendships and politics, most engagements are absolute s*%t shows with no order or direction anyway, the "work" looks good from the outside but in reality it's quite bland, as you're learning survival and crisis-management above all.

headline: IT auditor
pros:
Good exposure to clients ranging from big MNCs to medium enterprises.
Good exposure working in cross specialisation teams.
Good exposure if you intend to make audit your lifelong career
Flexible working arrangements (although expectation to overtime is an unspoken rule)
There are some good seniors and managers that are willing to coach and guide you and colleagues are generally friendly and approachable
Unlimited medical coverage from approved panel GP.
cons:
Career progression is quite linear. There are little to no specialist track and management path focuses more on selling service than quality of work performed and knowledge transfer.
Pay is below market rate for the first 3 years. Bonus and promotion is in September, where other big 4 firms have it earlier in June.
"work-life integration" means that you might not be able to go on leave or MC in peace
hard to switch specialisations within advisory due to internal politics
While there are changes to the appraisal and feedback system, it is still top down and lacks human touch. 
Too much emphasis on profit making: Allocate too little hours for work but promise client too much service resulting in staff burnout

The nature of the business is such that often you must stay late in the office and most of the seniors and managers don't arrive until often 9:30 or 10:00, which was hard because I like being to work by 8:00 or 8:30 but because it looks bad to go home before your senior, you will most likely end up staying late anyway.

headline: Various Experiences

Public accounting is not for everyone, but fresh out of college without much responsibilities public accounting is a unique experience. Chance of promotion and salary increase every year.
cons: Long hours from time to time. You have to be ready for busy season, and quarter ends if your with a public client. Salary is pretty low for what you may get in private.

headline: Good company and great program
pros: I'm "graduating" from TAP program soon. For the past 3 years, my experience at EY has been great. Competitive salaries, good raises every year, and fair review system.  The best part is the people. Almost every one I worked with, especially the Senior Managers and PPEDs, are super supportive. They're willing to have dinner with you in their spare time and talk about your future career development. They often take you to lunch or dinner out of their own pockets. TAP program is great too. TAP salary is higher than other programs and projects are more interesting.  The career trajectory is pretty good. You can have really fast growth at EY. EY overall is a little bit going downhill in recent years, but still has a lot of perks, like certification reimbursement and phone bill reimbursement. Honestly, if you are tight with a Partner, you can get a lot of stuff lol.
cons: EY's internal functions are really garbage. Many people consultants are very incompetent. My friend's people consultant almost forgot to do her Exit Interview on her last day. Immigration messes up things all the time and it's super slow and unresponsive. Our Time & Expense and Review system are so poorly designed. They must be procured by some partners who never do Expenses and Reviews themselves.

pros: Exposure of working in difference sectors , consumer products, insurance, energy and so on
cons: There is no promotion after getting to Assistant manager position

headline: Excellent start to your career
pros: Does wonders for your resume. It's like serious boot camp for your career. Loads of training/technical development. A ton of intelligent people to learn from constantly. You are always being challenged by both senior management and the clients.
cons: Same as with all big 4. Long hours with very little incentives. You're essentially on your own and HR is not useful as in a typical company. The pay does not compensate for the work you do, but there's delayed gratification in how much you can make when you leave. Very little work/life balance for those looking to raise a family and have a life outside of work.

headline: Know what you're getting into
pros: There are some nice people here, it pays well, the benefits and perks are solid, and if you want to do accounting or auditing, it's a good place to be, because that is most of what they do.
cons: Prepare to spend hours upon hours responding to pointless mass emails and doing unnecessary but mandatory administrative tasks that all employees must do on a regular basis, such as filling out independence forms, planning your hours for engagements in the future, recording time, filling out expense reports, explaining why you didn't spend the exact number of hours working as you predicted you would that week and therefore caused a variance, completing endless training modules, attending "counseling family" meetings and calls, writing self-reviews, asking for feedback in the feedback system, and I could go on and on. Also, there are nice people, but there is also the occasional soulless psychopath in management so try to avoid him or her. Additionally, a lot of the new hires and I were misled into thinking "Advisory" meant strategic business consulting, but it actually means either IT or financial auditing, depending on where EY decides to place you. The word "auditing" was NEVER thrown around during the recruiting process, and I would never have chosen to apply for the job had I known what it truly was. ALSO, one engagement I was on involved working in a trailer with no windows, no cell phones, and literal mice scurrying around and leaving droppings on the desks (which were already covered with dust and dirt to begin with), basically causing every day to become a Clorox-fest along with the 12 or 13 hours of IT auditing fun (I only worked eight, because I was planning to quit at that point and stopped caring, and was laughed at and frowned upon for this!). That being said, I also had some good experiences, getting to travel to various places in the country on some engagements (including NYC and Philadelphia), and working with some really great, smart people. I think it's possible to have a good experience here, but it's hit-or-miss, and you have to sort of wheedle your way into the good engagements and projects or else you will get stuck in something bad!

headline: Big potential but not employee friendly
pros:
- networking
- steep learning curve
 - you will be offered nice roles, good demand in the market
- colleagues are nice and supporting each other, very supportive, good memories.
cons:
- during Covid-19, employees are forced to come at least 2 days to the office.
- due to the new policy, some of our colleagues were positive, the only way to avoid it is to oppose the policy. 
A1 and interns are forced to come to the office every day. High risk due to the fact that these people come by public transportation. 
Badges are followed, emails are sent to people not coming to the office, it is a health issue and the long-term consequences of the disease are not clear. For me, this is absolutely irresponsible behavior. In case of health issues, I am sure that no one would take over responsibility. 
- the company tries to generate a growth rate of min 10% but the price for it is paid by its employees since the payment is lower compared to similar firms. 
- unnecessary, permanent pressure - too many feedbacks during one year, administrative work: expense reports, GTE reports is time-consuming.
- low number of resources which makes the completion of projects difficult, high quality is requested but the conditions for it are not offered.

headline: Good place to start career if you know what you want to be doing, very tiring and stressful though.
pros: It is a great name on your resume, finding a new job aftterwards is somewhat easy. There is a lot of training available, the trick is getting time off of your always-busy schedule to attend it. They have a defined benefit pension. Busy season perks (snack carts, happy  hours, etc). I think they try to be people-friendly as they say, but still fall short on the expectations of younger generations.
cons: Difficult to move into new departments within the firm and change the direction of your career. Heard that transfers to other locations are similarly difficult. The long hours, of course. The relatively low pay for those long hours (although I have heard other cities are not as bad pay-wise as cost of living is not so high as NYC). Perhaps the worst is that something about the review process ends up promoting and rewarding the wrong people - a lot of really mediocre people in senior and manager roles.

cons:

Lack of communication across many teams. Seniors are swamped with so much responsibility that they have no bandwidth to train and coach

headline: Good for the first 5 years of your career
pros:
I'm in business advisory and I'm speaking purely on a career perspective:

1. Great exposure to different industry
2. Increment is good until you manager level (especially if you are a performer)
3. Meet good friends along the way (subjective, as this is based on your personality)
4. It can't get any worse after EY
5. Guidance is there if you look for it (not always but most of the time)
cons:
1. Long hours
2. Accumulated OT is hardly utilized (OT utilization is on approval basis)
3. Some nasty managers
4. Burn out easily 
5. Only for Malaysia, a global company with a local management mindset

headline: You must really love auditing... and also office politics
pros:
- Get to audit multinational companies, listed companies, and private companies so you can obtain full scale of experience
- Good IT system and has clear instruction on every audit steps
- Get to act as a senior or manager role when you are in your first year
- Get to learn how to compile financial reports and tax reports
- Get to travel around but mostly to China
cons:
- Managers try not to let you claim for overtime or make you claim less overtime
- In peak season, your overtime hours usually exceed 120 hours/month
- A lot of office politics, especially among the management
- Male management or superior, especially those who served in military before, treat other males subordinate with disrespect
- Your pay is worse than working in McDonald
- Most of the time you need to get in during weekend and holiday and sometime camp in the office
- Very high turnover (like 30%/year), both in management level and in staff level

headline: Work life balance

headline: Best Company I have ever worked for.
pros: People focus and career development for those truly willing to go the extra mile.
cons: Nowhere is perfect.  Like any organization there can be politics or people jockying for advancement but typically (not always but mostly) it is at nobody else's expensse (back stabbing, etc.).  Generally your promoted, developed professionally, etc. according to your desire and contribution.  EY takes care of its people but you cant be a slacker which is no different as with most employers.  While your expected to be in charge of your own careen development (in certain respects) you are absolutely given the opportunity and tools to make it happen\.  The careen development and feedback system is very structured and consistent with deadlines, etc..  You also have a counselor and career advisor in addition to your supervisor.  Of course the benefits are outstanding.  They are not ranked in the top 100 company to work for by Forbes 15 years in a row (or so) and business week as the #1 place to start a career by accident. They recognize as a professional services organization your value is only as great as your people.

headline: E&Y is not a bad place to start your career.
pros: Outside of busy season, E&Y offers great flexability.  The firm is dedicated to ensuring you succeed both professonally and personally.  One of the many ways E&Y helps advance your career is by offering great training opportunities.  You have the opportunity to take to enroll in classes where you can learn about investment products, accounting topics, team management strategies, and many more.  Not only will the knowledge help you within the firm but also for careers outside the firm if you so happen to leave.  In addition to the great learning opportunities, E&Y has developed a great mentoring program.  The mentoring program pairs more seasoned employees with new hires.  This helps new hires get adjusting to the culture at E&Y.
cons: The increases in pay are moderate.

headline: Assurance Associate in GDS(Global Delivery Services)
pros:
1. Supportive team members.
2. Company sponsored higher education (ACCA & CPA). 
3. International secondment opportunities for months and even years.
4. Vibrant and diversified crowd.
cons:
1. Work-life imbalance during peak audit season. 
2. Sluggish and sometimes stagnant learning opportunities. 
3. Compensation not at par with the amount of work performed. 
4. Gruesome politics by seniors vying to be in the limelight.

headline: Manager
pros:
Good clients
Brand name
Travel perks (if you are travel savvy)
Office location (probably the best in New York)
16 weeks paternity leave
Competitive compensation
cons:
No work/life balance whatsover - if your project needs it, you need to work "25" out of 24 hours in a day. More often than not, you end up working that much since leadership wants to sell projects showing a small cost to the clients. Nobody cares if the team needs to put in extra hours coz they wont pay you any overtime money. At the max, you get a Bravo award ($50 or $100).
Lot of pressure when you are not on a project (bench time is the worst). Deployment WILL place you on any open position regardless of skillset.  Its purely body shopping business here.
Management indulges in petty politics and promotes those who are in the "like" bracket for them
Hard to move between practices
Glass ceiling - you cant grow beyond a certain role if you are not a sales person
Insurance premiums are probably the highest.

headline: Tax senior
pros: Good place to start your career; Lots of learning if you are on the right project; There are some great people in certain offices who are willing to teach and support junior people. However, it all depends on who you work with, not everyone is willing to teach and support each other.
cons: Long hours in the first few years. DSG model works and does not work for some people; It's good that tax associate can try various projects in different area in tax to find their interest but staff were thrown between groups and have to juggle different assignments; DSG model also delays your learning in the area you are actually want specialize in later on.
