There are lots of exit opportunities (provided you're in a career you enjoy) as many recruiters value the big 4 brand. It is a global firm as well, so lots of opportunities for mobility.
cons: It's a big firm and is rigid as a result. Trying to switch roles is almost impossible unless you have senior partners going to bat for you.

headline: Had potential, but sadly did not deliver
pros: Nice people, food benefits, decent vacation policy, huge company so there are many groups. That's about all there is to say here
cons:
Though my employment here was many years ago, during My time at EY, my managers and seniors were completely lacking in my professional development. They expected me to know what I was doing without formal training, and scolded me rather than helped me when I did not perform a task exactly the way I wanted. 

With such a large company, I do know others that had a better experience. Anther staff actually cried on multiple occasions during a project because our senior was THAT BAD. Sadly, my experience at EY completely turned me off to the field and I am much happier and much less stressed doing what I do now.

headline: Assistant Director
pros: Global opportunities, work from home, solid benefits
cons: Very little flexibility regarding work style - conformity is desired, especially when working with the Advisory function. In that case, partners have too much power over how and when employees on a project work, in many cases leading to a toxic work environment. Individual styles are not appreciated. Support functions like Communications who work with Advisory completely bend to the whims of those lead partners and rather than seek to find a compromise where their own employees are provided with support and solutions so that they can work comfortably, will sacrifice you in the name of the project, even if that project is dysfunctional and has a bad reputation within the company. Lots of employee churn within Advisory projects. You will be worked to death with very little reward or job satisfaction. As with other Big 4 firms, EY's support functions (Communications, Marketing, etc.) are second class to those functions that directly generate revenue.

headline: Good company to jumpstart your career, personal sucrifices are to be made if you want to progress
pros:
-Tons of opportunities to become proficient at your field (educated and experienced colleagues, trainings, e-learnings, paid qualifications (ACCA/ACA).
-Tons of opportunities to drive your career (you have to get out of your comfort zone though, do not expect that everything will be handed to you).
-Abroad trainings when progressing to senior/manager/senior manager (two things about that, 1) this is when you realize how big, diverse and truly global EY is, meeting up with numerous colleagues from all over and realizing your realities aren't that much different and 2) I have traveled a lot a I am an outgoing person, but I would have never believed that it would be such a memorable fun and truly one of a kind experience)
-You get to see prestigious companies from top to bottom and get to know their operations better than their own employees (full picture of the companies)
-Building a network inside and outside EY and starting to get recognized/known by the industry you operate in.
-Annual promotions keep you motivated.
-Overall being a multinational company, you get what you are promised (in terms of pay, leaves, whatever benefits etc)
cons:
-I would say long hours but its the nature of our job. Client serving professionals are assigned to projects that are expected to be completed by yesterday. So yea long hours. Depending on the project you may get a busy season of 2-4 months (12-14 hours a day, possibly weekends included) or a busy season of 6-8 months (12-14 hours a day out of which 2-4 months will include weekends as well). So yea you are probably getting to be overworked, but its always a choice.
-Pay is lower than what most industries pay, but it matches or surpasses them when accounting for overtimes (some offices offer paid overtime, while at others they are accumulated and compensated as leave days)

headline: Staff
pros: Good travelling benefits if you can get on a travelling project. Typical perks that come with big company.
cons:
1) No Career Growth/ Learning
Learned next to nothing in my years here except ppt and Excel, most of which I already knew before coming in. Training is a farce. They don't teach you how to think as other mgmt consulting firms do because you actually have no need in day to day work. No mentorship either. Thank goodness I know how to code, otherwise don't know how my skills will be transferable to anything else.

2) Lots of Politics
Lots and lots of politics. A - - kissing is a must. People don't care about you or your career growth just about covering their own behinds and how to make themselves look good.

3) Rewards Mediocrity and Shuns Excellence
As you go along you will see many smart people in the junior positions that filter out when you get to higher mgmt levels (manager, SM etc). This is not a coincidence. It's because of the aforementioned politics and general culture that rewards mediocrity and shuns excellence. Smart people tend to ask questions and voice their opinions when they think there is a better solution but you will find here that that is discouraged. It's expected that you just 'do your job' and 'don't ask questions' even when what your mgr is doing is clearly wrong and a day later you have to undo what you did and go in a different direction. 

4) Body Shop Projects
A lot of projects, esp in FS advisory is centered around big banks and AML. These are the most boring projects ever and you will find yourself repeatedly doing things even a monkey can do. The only reason they ask EY to do it is because EY has the brand name and since its primarily an audit firm it is 'trustworthy'. The reason why EY staffs so many of these projects instead of automating is because they can earn more $$ on each resource

headline: EY - more pros
pros: Best practices, many opportunities to develop, good work atmosphere, competitive salary. I have learned the work drill here and would recommend it to anyone who is treating job more than a neccesity.
cons: Pretty intense workflow and pressure for meeting the deadlines but i think it occurs in each big corporate structure. Whereas salary is competetive at big4 level i have a feeling that less recognizable comapnies which provide similar services offer bigger salary

headline: Great launchpad but not worth the long term effort unless you have great immediate leadership
pros:
Professional work environment.
Flexible working timing and you can work from home.
Great perks.
Lots of small recognition like gift vouchers, sporting events, social events
Excellent name to work with.
cons:
Long working hours.
Excess pressure from superiors
Work duplication
Some roles don’t have any growth, members have been in the same role for over 25 years with the same designation.
Some roles have exams to get certified, this is not documented on the offer letter. Its a lot of effort for something not recognized outside.

headline: Most Human of the Big 4
pros: Great brand, swish offices, driven people, big on D&I agenda, good variety of clients and opportunities to work abroad if that's your thing.
cons: As with other big 4, not for the work shy or those that don't like travel (in Advisory at least). Getting on means standing out amongst your peer group as a star and getting the right sponsors. That's easier for those that don't have other commitments and are naturally extrovert.

headline: Unfair

cons: Everything besides the brand name

headline: Read this if you're after an HR job at EY
pros: Office space, cafeteria amenities, equipment
cons: Many HR managers are former accounting managers and do not know anything about HR or people-centered approach to HR. They are finance-driven and take a traditional approach to HR where they act in the interest of the company's bottom line. Do not work here if you're looking for progressive HR programs or people who care about people. Recruiters are very good salespeople, different from the rest of the HR team, and tend to paint a pretty picture of the company, so don't be fooled.  The Learning team also feels they're "separate" from the HR team and like to operate differently. Once you're in, you're going to want to find another job!! Also, they take money out of your paycheque for health benefits... so it's not a benefit, more of a service!!
